questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for preoperative clearance for surgical placement of false teeth. The patient has a history of aortic stenosis and had a bioprosthetic replacement five years ago. The patient has no allergies. Which of the following describes the best treatment regimen prior to the surgery?

choices.text: Oral amoxicillin prior to the procedure
Oral ciprofloxacin prior to the procedure
Oral amoxicillin for two weeks prior to the procedure
Oral tetracycline prior to the procedure
Oral nafcillin prior to the procedure

questions.solution:
Patients at high risk for the development of endocarditis include patients with a history of prosthetic heart valves, history of infective endocarditis, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, or repaired congenital heart disease.  Patients with a history of these conditions that are undergoing dental procedures, skin or soft tissue procedures, or cardiorespiratory procedures should receive appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis.  

In most situations, appropriate antimicrobial prophylaxis includes a single dose of amoxicillin 30-60 minutes prior to the procedure. If patients are unable to tolerate oral intake, or they are undergoing an invasive procedure requiring sedation, intravenous third generation cephalosporins may be administered 30-60 minutes prior to the procedure. If allergic to penicillins, vancomycin can be administered 120 minutes prior to the procedure.    

Option Analysis

✅ Oral amoxicillin prior to the procedure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral ciprofloxacin prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Oral ciprofloxacin is commonly administered to patients for outpatient treatment of pyelonephritis. It is not considered a first line agent for antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients with a history of valvular disease undergoing surgical or dental procedures.   
❌ Oral amoxicillin for two weeks prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin is the appropriate agent to use as prophylaxis for those with risk factors for endocarditis; however, administration two weeks prior to the procedure is inappropriate and will likely lead to unwanted side effects.   
❌ Oral tetracycline prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Oral tetracycline is more commonly used for the outpatient treatment of community acquired pneumonia, rickettsial infections, and Lyme disease. It is not considered a first line agent for antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients with a history of valvular disease undergoing surgical or dental procedures.   
❌ Oral nafcillin prior to the procedure:
Incorrect: Nafcillin is effective against methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). However, it is not considered a first line agent for antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients with a history of valvular disease undergoing surgical or dental procedures.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an altercation. Per emergency medical services, the patient sustained a stab wound to the right anterior chest. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a 1 cm stab wound at the fourth intercostal space parasternally,  in addition to jugular venous distension. A bedside ultrasound of the patient’s heart is demonstrated below. A procedure to alleviate the worsening of this patient’s clinical condition should take place at which of the following anatomic locations?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia

choices.text: 4th or 5th intercostal space mid axillary line
4th or 5th intercostal space mid clavicular line

questions.solution:
This trauma patient presents with evidence cardiac tamponade on exam and bedside echocardiography. Pericardiocentesis is the treatment of choice in diagnosing and managing large, symptomatic pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.  This procedure involves using a large-bore needle to aspirate fluid from the pericardial sac to restore hemodynamic stability and improve cardiac output.  

The xiphoid process is palpated, and a needle is inserted inferiorly to the left costal margin at a 30-degree angle while aiming towards the left shoulder and aspirating in an apical approach. The physician may utilize an apical or parasternal approach to perform this procedure. An ultrasound may be performed to locate the largest effusion area at the 5th or 6th intercostal space parasternally if using the parasternal approach. Under ultrasound guidance, the needle may be inserted at this location, with a continual aspiration of fluid from the pericardium.  

During this procedure, structures at risk of injury include the internal thoracic artery, diaphragm, lungs, pleura, and the myocardium itself.    

 

Option Analysis

✅ Subxiphoid space:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 4th or 5th intercostal space mid axillary line:
Incorrect: The 4th or 5th intercostal space midaxillary line is the appropriate anatomic landmark for tube thoracostomy, not pericardiocentesis. 
❌ 2nd intercostal space midclavicular line :
Incorrect: The 2nd intercostal space midclavicular line is the appropriate location for needle decompression in the setting of tension pneumothorax, not for pericardiocentesis. 
❌ 4th or 5th intercostal space mid clavicular line:
Incorrect: The 4th or 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line is not appropriate for performing a pericardiocentesis. 
❌ Suprasternal space :
Incorrect: The suprasternal space is not an appropriate anatomical location for performing a pericardiocentesis.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man, who was brought into the emergency department by his friend, suddenly collapses in the waiting room. His t-shirt is saturated in blood, and he is immediately brought to the trauma bay. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a 1 cm stab wound over the left anterior chest wall, in addition to jugular venous distension. The jugular venous pulse is noted at the level of the mandible. The patient speaks in clear, complete sentences, and bilateral breath sounds are present. The telemetry rhythm strip is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?


Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with cardiac tamponade following penetrating chest trauma. He has jugular venous distension in addition to electrical alternans noted on telemetry. Given this patient’s unstable vital signs, he should immediately undergo transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and pericardiocentesis before definitive operative repair.

The acute management of adult chest pain follows a stepwise approach. First, patients should be evaluated for stability–including vital sign assessment, protection of airway, and mental status. Patients should immediately receive any necessary interventions to stabilize their airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients deemed unstable should be assessed for life-threatening causes of chest pain, such as myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, pericardial tamponade, tension pneumothorax, aortic dissection, and Boerhaave syndrome so appropriate intervention can be performed in a timely fashion. For example, immediate TTE and pericardiocentesis is indicated in the case of cardiac tamponade, and thrombolytics are indicated in the setting of massive pulmonary embolism.

Stable patients with chest pain should undergo further diagnostic workup to evaluate for more subtle presentations of a life-threatening diagnosis. All patients should receive an electrocardiogram to evaluate for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) or signs of ischemia. Specific ECG changes that suggest a life-threatening diagnosis include electrical alternans (pericardial tamponade) or an S1Q3T3 pattern (pulmonary embolism – though remember, the most common ECG finding in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia).

Next, most patients with chest pain who have ECG changes should be further evaluated with laboratory testing using serial troponin assays to evaluate for underlying cardiac ischemia and non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Stable patients should also have chest radiography, which can assess for the presence of a pneumothorax, mediastinal air suggestive of esophageal perforation, or a widened mediastinum suggestive of aortic dissection.


Option Analysis

✅ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Thoracotomy:
Incorrect: Bedside thoracotomy should be reserved for pulseless patients who received CPR less than 15 minutes after traumatic thoracic injury. This trauma patient has evidence of unstable vital signs but is not pulseless.
❌ Needle decompression:
Incorrect: Needle decompression is indicated for patients with suspected pneumothorax. Patients with this condition will have evidence of diminished breath sounds following trauma.
❌ Intubation:
Incorrect: This patient is currently protecting his airway, and thus intubation is not currently indicated. Moreover, intubation may worsen this patient’s hypotension, resulting in cardiac arrest.
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: Chest radiography should only be obtained once this patient is stabilized and is therefore not currently indicated.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department with shortness of breath, which began four hours ago. The patient also has swelling of the bilateral lower extremities. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and congestive heart failure. At arrival, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 145/87 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. Physical examination reveals bibasilar inspiratory crackles and pitting edema in the lower extremities. Imaging is ordered and reveals the findings below. Laboratory testing reveals a sodium level of 135 mEq/L and potassium of 5.3 mEq/L. Concurrent administration of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath, peripheral edema, and increased lung shadowing on the x-ray in the setting of congestive heart disease. He most likely has pulmonary edema. Laboratory testing reveals hyperkalemia. To avoid exacerbating the electrolyte abnormality or triggering an arrhythmia, patients with hyperkalemia should avoid taking potassium-sparing diuretics.

Potassium-sparing diuretics are used in the treatment of hypertension and edematous states, such as pulmonary edema and abdominal ascites. This is because potassium-sparing diuretics increase sodium and water loss via urine, which helps decrease plasma volume, cardiac output, and extracellular fluid volume. In addition, potassium-sparing diuretics that act as aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) are useful in treating conditions associated with hyperaldosteronism (e.g., adrenal adenoma, adrenal hyperplasia).

Finally, spironolactone and amiloride can bind to androgen receptors and prevent testosterone from binding. These medications help blunt the effects of testosterone in the body and can be used to manage conditions such as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Of note, spironolactone has stronger antiandrogenic properties and is used more commonly than amiloride to treat PCOS.

Side effects on these medications include hyperkalemia (due to reduced potassium excretion) and metabolic acidosis (due to reduced potassium excretion). In addition, spironolactone can cause gynecomastia as a side effect.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Triamterene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: This patient has pulmonary and peripheral edema, likely due to congestive heart failure exacerbation. Laboratory testing reveals hyperkalemia and medications that increase serum potassium levels should be used with caution, as they may exacerbate hyperkalemia and cause arrhythmias. However, metformin does not typically increase serum potassium levels.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes hypokalemia as a side effect. As a result, it can be administered safely to this patient, who has hyperkalemia.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is an antihypertensive that causes vasodilation. Side effects include headache, reflex tachycardia, and lupus-like syndrome. However, it does not exacerbate hyperkalemia. Hence, hydralazine can be safely administered to this patient.  
❌ Glyburide:
Incorrect: Glyburide is a medication that increases endogenous insulin release. Side effects include disulfiram-like reactions, hypoglycemia, and weight gain. However, glyburide would not typically cause hyperkalemia and would not exacerbate this patient’s electrolyte abnormality.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and palpitations for 2 hours. Past medical history is significant for congestive heart failure, nonischemic cardiomyopathy, and hypertension. Current medications include furosemide, metoprolol, lisinopril, and digoxin. The patient’s ejection fraction on transthoracic echocardiography a month ago was 40%. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows absent P waves with an irregularly irregular rhythm and nonspecific T wave changes. The patient is started on apixaban and amiodarone. His symptoms improved during the hospital stay, and he was discharged home on day three, with these new medications added to his regimen. He returns to the emergency department a week later with generalized fatigue, nausea, non-bloody vomiting, and nonspecific abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s current presentation with generalized fatigue, nausea, non-bloody vomiting, and nonspecific abdominal pain suggests digoxin toxicity, most likely due to the addition of amiodarone to the patient’s medication regimen.

Acute toxicity can present with nausea, vomiting, hyperkalemia, and cardiac arrhythmias (sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial tachycardia with AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation). In contrast, chronic toxicity presents with less profound gastrointestinal symptoms and more significant neurological (e.g., lethargy, fatigue, and confusion) and visual (e.g., changes in color vision and scotomas) symptoms.

Amiodarone, verapamil, quinidine, or propafenone (when coadministered with digoxin) can increase the risk of digoxin toxicity by reducing its renal excretion (competing for or inhibiting P-glycoprotein) or by displacement of digoxin from tissue binding sites. This leads to increased serum levels in a patient who has previously been on a stable digoxin regimen. It is recommended to decrease the dose of digoxin by 20-50% when initiating therapy with any of these drugs.

Other factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity include:

  • Hypokalemia which can increase digoxin binding at the K+-binding site on Na+/K+ ATPase
  • Hypomagnesemia (which leads to hypokalemia)
  • Renal failure (decreased digoxin clearance)
 


Option Analysis

❌ Erosive gastritis:
Incorrect: Erosive gastritis can present with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. This patient's presentation with generalized fatigue in a possible drug interaction makes this unlikely.  
❌ Pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis usually presents with nausea, vomiting, and epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back in predisposing factors (e.g., excessive alcohol use and gallstones). This patient’s presentation is not typical of pancreatitis.  
✅ Drug interaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Apixaban toxicity:
Incorrect: Apixaban is an anticoagulant, and its toxicity can present with bleeding gums, epistaxis, hematuria, melena, or hematochezia, none of which are seen in this patient.  
❌ Heart failure exacerbation:
Incorrect: Heart failure exacerbation usually presents with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, cough, early satiety, weight gain, and increasing abdominal girth. It is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s presentation.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic because of shortness of breath that has progressively worsened over the past few weeks. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic calculous cholecystitis. The patient was recently diagnosed with new-onset diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and olmesartan/amlodipine. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 90 bpm, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient’s skin appears bronze. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S3 gallop with a pansystolic murmur over the mitral area. Auscultation of the chest reveals bilateral rales extending from the bases to the mid-lobar regions. There is 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. The basic metabolic panel is shown below. Which of the following historical elements would be expected given this patient’s most likely underlying condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  10.5 g/dl  
 Leukocyte count  4500 /mm3 
 Platelets  165,000/ mm3 
 INR   1.9 
 Creatinine  1.1 mg/dl 
 Albumin   2.3 g/dl 
 Bilirubin (Total)  1.5 mg/dl 
 Iron   200 mcg/dL 
 Serum ferritin  430 ng/mL 
 Transferrin serum iron saturation (TSAT)  65% (normal: 20-50%) 
 AST  98 U/L 
 ALT   100 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of new-onset heart failure and diabetes mellitus associated with bronze skin; and elevated liver enzymes, ferritin level, and transferrin saturation. The most likely diagnosis is hemochromatosis, which can be associated with a family history of liver disease since primary hemochromatosis is associated with a genetic mutation in the HEF gene.    

Hemochromatosis (i.e., iron overload) can be classified based on the etiology as primary (i.e., genetic mutation) or secondary (i.e., associated with alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, HCV infection, thalassemia, sickle cell disease, multiple blood transfusions, or excessive oral iron supplementation).  

Primary hemochromatosis is caused by an autosomal recessive mutation in the HFE gene which is responsible for controlling iron absorption from the small intestine. Iron accumulation leads to long-term oxidative stress, subsequently inducing irreversible organ damage. There are rare cases of non-HFE hereditary hemochromatosis which can be tested for if there is high suspicion and HFE gene testing is negative.  

Signs and symptoms of hemochromatosis result from iron accumulation in several organ systems, which can be seen in this patient. Iron deposition in the skin can result in bronze discoloration of the skin. Iron deposition in the pancreas can lead to diabetes mellitus, and iron deposition in the myocardium can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy. Other manifestations of hemochromatosis include arthropathy (2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal joints), and liver cirrhosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of liver disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of IV drug use :
Incorrect: History of prior IV drug use is a significant risk factor for chronic viral hepatitis; however, given this patient's findings consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy, bronze skin,and alterations in iron metabolism (i.e., high iron and transferrin saturation), hemochromatosis is more likely the cause of his elevated liver enzymes.
❌ History of chronic alcohol use:
Incorrect: Chronic alcoholic consumption is associated with abnormalities of liver enzymes and functions; however, it is not associated with an elevation in the TSAT. Also, alcoholic liver disease is typically associated with an AST/ALT ratio of 2:1 or greater which is not seen in this patient.
❌ History of lipid-lowering drug use:
Incorrect: Statins (e.g., atorvastatin) are associated with variable degrees of hepatotoxicity ranging from asymptomatic elevations in the liver enzymes to fulminant hepatitis; however, this medication is not associated with abnormalities in the iron profile, bronze skin, new-onset diabetes, and dilated cardiomyopathy.
❌ History of autoimmune disease:
Incorrect: Autoimmune hepatitis is associated with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain. Additionally, it is associated with a marked rise in serum AST and ALT levels which is not seen in this patient, and it would not account for the abnormal iron studies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive difficulty breathing, which has been ongoing for the last 2 days. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and heart failure with an ejection fraction of 31%. The patient does not take his medications and consumes salty foods. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows a man with labored breathing and bilateral lower extremity edema. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral crackles. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous furosemide. This medication acts on which of the following regions of the nephron?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute decompensated heart failure. The mainstay of management involves intravenous diuresis, typically with a loop diuretic such as furosemide.        

In the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide, bumetanide, torsemide) bind and inhibit the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter. As a result, sodium, potassium, and chloride cannot be reabsorbed into the bloodstream and get excreted out with the urine. Other ions that depend on sodium reabsorption, such as calcium and magnesium, are excreted as well. These changes ultimately lead to decreased water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.        

Major indications for loop diuretics include hypertension and edematous states (e.g., heart failure, ascites, acute pulmonary edema). Moreover, these medications can also be used to correct certain electrolyte imbalances such as hypercalcemia and hyperkalemia. Lastly, loop diuretics are also effective in treating acute bromide, fluoride, or iodide intoxications because these substances are also reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb.  



Option Analysis

❌ Region A:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, thereby blocking NaHCO3, and water reabsorption and resulting in urinary bicarbonate wasting. It is used to relieve intracranial pressure in idiopathic intracranial hypertension and intraocular pressure in glaucoma. Furosemide, in contrast, acts on a different part of the nephron. 
❌ Region B:
Incorrect: The descending loop of Henle carries fluid from the proximal tubule to the ascending loop of Henle. It allows reabsorption of water into the interstitial fluids to produce concentrated urine. However, loop diuretics such as furosemide act on a different part of the nephron. 
✅ Region C:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Region D:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) act on the early distal tubule, where they inhibit Na+/Cl- contransporters. 
❌ Region E:
Incorrect: Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act on the collecting tubules. Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, do not act here.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath and orthopnea. Past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and myocardial infarction, which occurred 9 months ago. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure and pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral crackles. The patient is treated with a medication that results in brisk diuresis and subsequent symptomatic improvement. The patient is sent home on this medication. Three weeks later, laboratory analysis revealed reduced serum calcium and magnesium levels. The diuretic prescribed to this patient predominantly acts on which of the following nephron segments?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of acute decompensated heart failure. The mainstay of management is intravenous diuresis, typically with a loop diuretic such as furosemide.        

Loop diuretics act on the ascending limb of the loop of Henle by binding and inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter. Inhibition of sodium chloride reabsorption also inhibits the back leak of potassium into the tubule and prevents the generation of a positive intraluminal potential within the ascending loop of Henle. As a result, there is a decreased electrical gradient for magnesium and calcium reabsorption and increased loss of magnesium and calcium via urine. Due to these effects, loop diuretics can cause hypomagnesemia and hypocalcemia.    

Option Analysis

❌ Proximal tubule:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, thereby blocking NaHCO3, and water reabsorption and resulting in urinary bicarbonate wasting. Acetazolamide may cause metabolic acidosis, but not hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. 
❌ Descending loop of Henle:
Incorrect: The descending loop of Henle is not a common site of action for diuretics. 
✅ Thick ascending loop of Henle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Distal tubule:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics (e.g. hydrochlorothiazide) act on the early distal tubule and inhibit NaCl reabsorption. While thiazide diuretics may cause hypomagnesemia, they do not typically cause hypocalcemia. 
❌ Cortical collecting duct :
Incorrect: Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act on collecting duct systems. However, these medications are not typically associated with hypocalcemia or hypomagnesemia.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents to the emergency department after vomiting a large volume of black material that morning. Past medical history is significant for alcohol-induced cirrhosis. The patient has not experienced gastrointestinal bleeding in the past. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 92/52 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. He is alert and oriented, and able to answer questions appropriately. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nondistended with epigastric tenderness to palpation. Skin examination reveals palmar erythema and spider angiomas on the trunk and bilateral upper extremities. Laboratory results are shown below. What is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     8.4  g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     11,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     90,000/mm3    
 AST     30 U/L    
 ALT     22 U/L    
 PT     29s    
 aPT     27s

choices.text: Intravenous access with two large-bore intravenous lines

questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol-induced cirrhosis presents after an episode of large-volume hematemesis, which is suggestive of an upper gastrointestinal bleed. The patient is tachycardic and hypotensive, indicating potential hypovolemic shock. The immediate priority is to obtain intravenous access with two large-bore intravenous (IV) lines that allow for rapid administration of fluids and/or blood products to restore intravascular volume and maintain organ perfusion.       

Patients with chronic liver disease are at increased risk of bleeding due to hemostatic abnormalities. These can include thrombocytopenia, reduced platelet function, and coagulation factor deficiencies leading to prolonged PT.       

For unstable patients presenting with hemorrhagic shock, intravenous fluids should be administered and transfusion of blood products such as packed red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, or cryoprecipitate should be considered. It is crucial to promptly identify and address the bleeding source. Neurologic changes may indicate intracranial bleeding, while hematemesis and hematochezia suggest GI bleeding, and profuse vaginal bleeding after delivery is considered a postpartum hemorrhage. If the bleeding source is not apparent, imaging such as CT (Computed Tomography) angiography or procedures like endoscopy might be needed, alongside surgical consultation for potential intervention.        

Option Analysis

❌ Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion:
Incorrect: While proton pump inhibitor infusion is used in the management of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, the immediate concern in a bleeding and unstable patient like this one is to ensure hemodynamic stability by providing intravenous fluid resuscitation. This can only occur after intravenous access is established.  
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: Intubation should be considered in patients with upper GI bleeding if there is concern for airway protection, (i.e., ongoing large-volume emesis, altered mental status), or if urgent endoscopic evaluation is needed. Although this patient has vomited a significant amount of blood, he remains alert and oriented, indicating that airway protection is not immediately necessary. 
✅ Intravenous access with two large-bore intravenous lines:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Urgent endoscopic evaluation:
Incorrect: Endoscopy is a critical component of the management of gastrointestinal bleeding for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. However, it should be performed after the patient has been appropriately resuscitated and is hemodynamically optimized. 
❌ Antibiotic prophylaxis :
Incorrect: Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended in patients with cirrhosis who present with gastrointestinal bleeding to prevent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and other infections. However, these should be administered after the patient has been adequately resuscitated and stabilized.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a two-day history of shortness of breath and confusion. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (last estimated to be 20%). The patient reports infrequent follow-up visits and medication nonadherence. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 73/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cool extremities, jugular venous distention, and diffuse crackles in the lungs. Treatment with intravenous agents is started. The agents specifically decrease the rate of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (AMP) degradation via the inhibition of an enzyme. Which of the following is an example of the drug used in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with worsening dyspnea, confusion, bibasilar crackles, and JVD is consistent with cardiogenic shock secondary to heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). An intravenous milrinone (a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor) infusion is started in this patient to improve cardiac contractility.

PDE-3 inhibitors, such as milrinone and enoximone, decrease the rate of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (AMP) degradation. The ensuing increase in cyclic AMP concentration leads to enhanced calcium influx into the cell, a rise in cell calcium concentration, and increased contractility. These drugs also cause systemic arterial and venous dilation, viral causes of vascular PDE. Milrinone is used as an inotropic agent in acute heart failure. It should not be used in chronic heart failure because it increases morbidity and mortality. Side effects include arrhythmias and hypotension due to significant vasodilation.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Milrinone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dobutamine:
Incorrect: Dobutamine is a highly selective beta-agonist for beta-1 receptors. It is coupled to Gs protein, which stimulates adenylate cyclase. This increases the production of cAMP (rather than decreasing its degradation) in the target cells leading to an increase in calcium influx into the cells and the force of cardiac muscle contraction (positive inotropy and chronotropy).  
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Digoxin acts by direct inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase, indirectly inhibiting Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, leading to increased calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This calcium increases cardiac contractility (positive inotropy) when this calcium is released. It does not affect AMP degradation, an effect similar to that of milrinone.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: ACE inhibitors (ACEI) such as captopril, enalapril, or lisinopril, inhibit the action of ACE and prevent the formation of angiotensin II and aldosterone and results in an increase in endogenous vasodilators of the kinin family. It is indicated in hypertension, heart failure, and diabetic nephropathy.  
❌ Dapagliflozin:
Incorrect: Dapagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that reduces blood glucose by increasing urinary glucose excretion and is used to reduce the risk of progression of diabetic kidney disease. It is a treatment option for patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a cough and shortness of breath. He states that these symptoms have been gradually worsening, but recently, he woke up in the middle of the night suddenly feeling short of breath. He sleeps in a recliner because he gets short of breath while lying flat. Past medical history of obesity and hypertension, which is currently not treated. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 187/108 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 98% in room air. Physical examination shows mild jugular venous distention. Mild bibasilar crackles are noted on chest auscultation. Which of the following substances will be produced in the small pulmonary vessels in response to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with cough and shortness of breath, jugular venous distension, and bibasilar crackles are suggestive of decompensated heart failure. The decrease in cardiac output leads to renal hypoperfusion and the subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).    

When blood pressure is low, blood flow to the kidneys decreases. The kidneys respond by secreting renin into the bloodstream. Renin is a proteolytic enzyme that breaks down a protein made in the liver called angiotensinogen, and this gives rise to angiotensin I. When angiotensin I reaches the lungs, angiotensin I is converted into angiotensin II by an enzyme called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the pulmonary vessels. Angiotensin II binds to receptors in vascular smooth muscle and causes them to constrict, which increases the blood pressure. Finally, angiotensin II also stimulates the release of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone increases the reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys, which also increases water reabsorption. This results in increased blood volume, which also increases blood pressure.  



Option Analysis

❌ Renin:
Incorrect: Renin is secreted by the juxtaglomerular cells in the kidney in response to decreased cardiac output leading to renal hypoperfusion.  
❌ Angiotensin I:
Incorrect: Angiotensinogen is converted to angiotensin I in the systemic circulation via the action of renin.   
✅ Angiotensin II:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aldosterone:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II acts on the adrenal glands to stimulate the production and release of aldosterone, which acts on the collecting duct of the nephron to retain sodium and water.  
❌ Prostaglandin E1:
Incorrect: Prostaglandins are produced by endothelial cells, macrophages, and mast cells. It acts on the afferent arterioles of the nephron to cause vasodilation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of three days of shortness of breath and a new cough. The patient has a history of difficulty controlling hypertension and takes multiple antihypertensives. Previously, the patient was active and could walk up two to three flights of stairs before stopping to catch his breath, but now he can only walk up three steps before stopping. The patient has a significant smoking history. Temperature is 37.1 ºC (98.8 ºF), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 146/84 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is not in acute distress. On lung exam, crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is mild pedal edema bilaterally. Transthoracic echocardiogram performed four months ago show preserved ejection fraction. Which of the following tests should be performed initially to help determine the underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the chest

questions.solution:
This patient with a significant smoking history and difficult-to-control hypertension presents with new shortness of breath and an acute cough. Given the finding of pulmonary crackles on auscultation and mild peripheral edema, the presentation is suggestive of congestive heart failure (CHF). However, new onset chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) cannot be ruled out in this patient. A serum proBNP level can be performed initially to help differentiate between CHF and other etiologies. A significantly elevated serum proBNP level is indicative of CHF.    

Acute cough can be due to several cardiopulmonary pathologies and generally refers to a cough present for less than 3 weeks. If the history and physical examination do not reveal an obvious cause of the cough, the next step is to obtain a chest radiograph. For patients with a normal chest radiograph, consider pulmonary embolism, viral bronchitis, gastroesophageal reflux disease, medication side effects, and exacerbation of COPD. For patients with an abnormal chest radiograph, consider bacterial pneumonia, bronchiectasis exacerbation in a patient with known bronchiectasis, and congestive heart failure (CHF).    

In some cases, such as in patients with both COPD and CHF, it can be difficult to discern between primary cardiac or primary pulmonary etiology. While a transthoracic echocardiogram should be performed, it may take several hours before it is performed and interpreted and often does not change management. Serum proBNP measurement is an appropriate initial test to help narrow down the differential diagnosis. This test is comparatively inexpensive, and results return quickly. While proBNP measurements alone are not necessarily diagnostic, an acutely elevated level suggests cardiac etiology rather than pulmonary etiology.   

Option Analysis

✅ Serum pro B-type natriuretic peptide (proBNP):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pulmonary function tests:
Incorrect: Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are useful to differentiate between various pulmonary pathologies (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, interstitial lung disease) or in cases of idiopathic dyspnea. PFTs are not appropriate in the acute setting as they do not provide accurate results in this scenario. 
❌ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transthoracic echocardiogram should be repeated to determine if there has been a decrease in ejection fraction or other findings. However, a serum proBNP can be performed quickly to determine if the findings are due to congestive heart failure or new onset chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 
❌ Urine pneumococcal antigen:
Incorrect: This test can be useful to determine the specific bacterial etiology in patients with community-acquired pneumonia. This patient’s lack of fever and pulmonary auscultation findings are more consistent with new onset congestive heart failure and not pneumonia. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the chest:
Incorrect: CT imaging with pulmonary embolism (PE) protocol is used to assess for pulmonary embolism. This patient has no risk factors for PE and does not have tachycardia, chest pain, or significant hypoxemia, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department for evaluation of progressively worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, and palpitations over the last three days. She describes the chest pain as constant, dull, and non-radiating. She developed flu-like symptoms 3 days ago. Initially, she experienced shortness of breath with exertion, but she now struggles to breathe at rest. She appears to be in moderate respiratory distress. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, heart rate is 125 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On physical examination, there is jugular venous distension, bilateral rales on lung auscultation, and bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities. ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment changes and sinus tachycardia. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) reveals a severely reduced ejection fraction of 25% with global hypokinesis. The patient is started on supplemental oxygen and a dobutamine infusion. Which of the following is the best next step in management if the patient continues to have hypotension despite these initial measures?
questions.solution:
For patients with fulminant myocarditis and cardiogenic shock, initial supportive measures include respiratory and circulatory support. Patients may require intubation and mechanical ventilation. Inotropic agents like dobutamine should be given for circulatory support. When patients fail to respond to these measures, the next step is to initiate mechanical circulatory support (MCS), such as extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). These interventions provide temporary support by improving cardiac output and oxygenation, allowing time for the heart to recover or until more definitive therapy (e.g., heart transplantation) can be considered.       

Treatment of myocarditis begins with supportive care, which includes oxygen therapy, management of fluid balance, and inotropic support to improve cardiac output in cases of heart failure. For patients who remain unstable despite the use of inotropic agents or for those with fulminant myocarditis, mechanical circulatory support (MCS), such as extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP), may be necessary to maintain perfusion and support cardiac function during cardiac recovery. Immunosuppressive therapies like corticosteroids, cyclosporine, or azathioprine may be considered in certain cases. If the myocardium is severely damaged and unresponsive to treatment, heart transplantation may be necessary for survival in patients with irreversible cardiac failure.       

Option Analysis

✅ Mechanical circulatory support:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral prednisone:
Incorrect: This patient has fulminant myocarditis with cardiogenic shock. In critical cases, immediate respiratory and circulatory support with intravenous therapies and mechanical mechanisms may be required to stabilize the patient. This should be done before corticosteroids are given intravenously. 
❌ Heart transplantation :
Incorrect: Heart transplantation is a last resort option for patients with myocarditis who do not respond to intravenous inotropic agents and mechanical circulatory support. 
❌ Oral diuretics:
Incorrect: Oral diuretics are inadequate for treating fulminant myocarditis with cardiogenic shock. This patient requires emergent intravenous inotropic agents and mechanical circulatory support if there is inadequate response to inotropes to stabilize hemodynamics. 
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: Pericardiocentesis is indicated for patients presenting with cardiac tamponade or large pericardial effusions, neither of which are seen on this patient’s echocardiogram. This patient in cardiogenic shock from myocarditis should have intravenous inotropic agents and mechanical circulatory support if there is inadequate response to inotropes to stabilize hemodynamics.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of worsening shortness of breath for the past two months. She reports an increase in lower extremity swelling, abdominal fullness, and early satiety. The patient recalls an episode of chest pressure and discomfort approximately three months ago for which she did not seek treatment. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia; and she has been intermittently compliant with amlodipine, metformin, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is in no acute distress and is resting comfortably on the examination table. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals a right-sided S3. She has notable jugular venous distention, 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities bilaterally, and abdominal distention with a positive fluid wave. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. An electrocardiogram reveals normal sinus rhythm with Q-waves in the inferior leads. An echocardiogram is ordered and reveals impaired right ventricular (RV) wall motion and a reduced RV ejection fraction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings consistent with right heart failure, including dyspnea, lower extremity edema, early satiety, a right sided S3, jugular venous distention, and ascites. The preceding episode of chest pain, along with findings of inferior Q-waves on ECG, and echocardiogram demonstrating right ventricular wall motion abnormalities suggest myocardial disease as the cause of right heart failure. This patient likely sustained an inferior myocardial infarction for which she did not seek treatment, resulting in right heart failure.        

Right heart failure occurs when the right side of the heart fails to adequately perfuse the pulmonary arterial circulation, resulting in elevated central venous pressure. In stable patients, this condition often presents with historical elements of chronic dyspnea, chest discomfort, fatigue, early satiety, or abdominal fullness. Physical examination may reveal jugular venous distention, hepatojugular reflux, bilateral lower extremity edema, or evidence of ascites (e.g. positive fluid wave). Cardiac exam will typically reveal a right ventricular heave, loud P2 (if caused by pulmonary hypertension), and right-sided S3. Importantly, there should be no evidence of pulmonary edema, unless concurrent left-sided heart failure is present.        

Diagnostic findings suggestive of right heart failure include an elevated BNP, evidence of congestive hepatopathy (including elevated AST, ALT, and bilirubin), and elevations in BUN and creatinine (due to cardiorenal syndrome). ECG may demonstrate right axis deviation, right atrial enlargement, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It may also provide clues to a prior inferior myocardial infarction with Q-waves). Chest X-ray may reveal a globular cardiac silhouette with rightward displacement. Additionally, echocardiogram may show evidence of RV dysfunction and right ventricular (RV) wall motion abnormalities and a reduced RV ejection fraction, indicating prior inferior myocardial infarction (as seen in this case). Additional testing, such as right-heart catheterization or a cardiac MRI, may be necessary.   

Option Analysis

✅ Myocardial disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Valvular disease:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is more consistent with an inferior MI, causing right heart failure. Tricuspid or pulmonic valve disease would be suspected if this patient had a typical murmur on examination and echocardiographic findings demonstrating regurgitation or stenosis of the affected valves. 
❌ Pulmonary hypertension:
Incorrect: Echocardiographic findings that would be expected with pulmonary hypertension include an elevated estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure, enlarged right atrium and ventricle, and signs of RV strain. Patients with pulmonary hypertension typically have a history of an associated risk factor (e.g. family history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic structural lung disease). This patient's history and findings are more consistent with an inferior MI as the cause of right heart failure. 
❌ Cardiac tamponade:
Incorrect: Patients with cardiac tamponade will generally be hemodynamically unstable. Echocardiographic findings would include a large pericardial effusion with right atrial and ventricular collapse during diastole. 
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Echocardiographic findings suggestive of pulmonary embolism include a hyperkinetic apex, D-sign, and RV strain. The findings in this vignette are more consistent with inferior myocardial infarction, causing right heart failure.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an episode of syncope at home. The patient is unable to provide a history due to altered mental status. The patient’s wife states that he had been in his usual state of health. This morning the patient stood up from a chair, went into the bathroom, and suddenly collapsed. The patient has not seen a physician in several years and takes no medications. The patient smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day and does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 36.0 °C (96.8 °F), blood pressure is 88/50 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.  The patient is ill-appearing and pale, and has cool clammy extremities. A midline abdominal mass is palpated. Rectal examination is unremarkable. Blood glucose is within normal limits. The patient is started on intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Results from initial blood work are detailed below. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after an episode of syncope, for which there is a broad differential diagnosis. This patient with a significant smoking history has bloodwork showing anemia, and an abdominal mass on physical exam. In addition, the patient has evidence of hypovolemic shock on examination. Together these findings are concerning for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm which is best diagnosed via abdominal ultrasound.

Hypovolemic shock refers to a life-threatening condition defined by organ hypoperfusion secondary to decreased intravascular volume. Hypovolemic shock can be defined as hemorrhagic or non-hemorrhagic. Hemorrhagic shock is associated with blood loss which can be seen in traumatic conditions – such as a ruptured spleen – or non-traumatic conditions like variceal bleeding or abdominal aortic rupture, as is likely in this case. Non-hemorrhagic shock is associated with fluid loss, most commonly from volume depletion as occurs after prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, as well as with severe widespread burns.

Initial diagnostic workup for patients with suspected hypovolemic shock includes obtaining blood work including CBC, lactate, CMP, PT, PTT, INR. When the presentation is unclear (e.g. no evidence of trauma on examination) several biomarkers can assist with differentiating between hemorrhagic and non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock. In general, patients with hemorrhagic shock will have new or worsening anemia and will have derangements in coagulation studies if coagulopathy is present. Patients with non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock will often have an elevated hemoglobin consistent with hemoconcentration. Both hemorrhagic and non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock can present with acute kidney injury, lactic acidosis, and elevated transaminases.

Option Analysis

✅ Order an abdominal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology for upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient presentation is not consistent with acute upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage which typically presents with melena or hematemesis. Additionally, this patient lacks risk factors for an upper GI bleed like liver disease or NSAID use. This patient’s presentation is concerning for an intra-cavity (e.g. intraperitoneal) source of bleeding likely a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Consult gastroenterology for a colonoscopy:
Incorrect:  This patient presentation is not consistent with a lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage which typically presents with bright red blood per rectum.  
❌ Order chest radiograph:
Incorrect: Obtaining a chest radiograph is unlikely to provide significant diagnostic information for determining the etiology of the suspected internal hemorrhage.  
❌ Administer norepinephrine:
Incorrect: Administration of vasoactive agents should be reserved for patients presenting with hypotension who fail to respond to fluid resuscitation, and in cases of hemorrhagic shock, blood products as well. This patient has a suspected underlying hemorrhage and should receive packed red blood cells and IV fluids for resuscitation prior to using vasoactive agents.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for dark tarry stools. The patient first noticed dark stools 2 to 3 days prior, along with lightheadedness, dizziness and mild epigastric pain.  The patient drinks 6 to 7 beers daily and takes naproxen daily for osteoarthritis pain. He has no other medical history. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 87/53 mmHg, pulse is 118/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears pale. There is tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region. Digital rectal examination shows melena. The patient is started on intravenous fluids and bloodwork is obtained. The initial results are detailed below. Which of the following should be ordered next?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with new onset melena, concerning for an upper gastrointestinal bleed, and clinical findings of hemorrhagic shock.  Given these concerns, upper endoscopy is the best next step in management.

On evaluation of patients with hemorrhagic shock, they will typically have evidence of new or worsening anemia and/or evidence of obvious bleeding on examination. If patients have evidence of obvious bleeding, they should receive blood product resuscitation which may include packed RBCs, platelets, and fresh frozen plasma. These patients should also receive intravenous fluids as needed, and prompt surgical or gastroenterology consultation depending on the bleeding source. In patients with evidence of hemorrhagic shock but without an obvious source of bleeding or trauma, further history may reveal the underlying cause. For example, evidence of melena or hematochezia suggests a gastrointestinal source of bleeding. Patients with a suspected upper gastrointestinal bleed should have an upper endoscopy (EGD), and those with a suspected lower gastrointestinal bleed should have a colonoscopy. Certain patients may be considered for interventional radiology consultation for possible arterial embolization depending on the source of bleeding. In some cases, the source of bleeding is unclear based on history or examination and patients need imaging to evaluate for an internal source of bleeding using CT of the abdomen and pelvis or abdominal ultrasound.

Patients with non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock typically have evidence of hemoconcentration on CBC without any evidence of anemia and a history consistent with fluid loss. They should have crystalloid fluid resuscitation while assessing organ systems and determining the underlying cause.  

Option Analysis

✅ Upper endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is not consistent with a lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage which typically presents with bright red blood per rectum. Colonoscopy is unlikely to have diagnostic utility for this patient.  
❌ CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: In patients with hypovolemic shock and evidence of blood loss but without a suspected source, abdominal imaging should be obtained to evaluate for an internal source of bleeding like ruptured aortic aneurysm. The presence of melena, possible alcohol use disorder, and frequent NSAID use suggest an upper GI source of bleeding.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: In patients presenting with hypovolemic shock from blood loss but without a suspected source, abdominal imaging should be obtained to evaluate for an internal source of bleeding. The presence of melena, possible alcohol use disorder, and frequent NSAID use suggest a GI source of bleeding.  
❌ Ketorolac for pain control:
Incorrect:  Administration of ketorolac is contraindicated given this patient's anemia and impaired renal function. Administration of NSAIDs may ultimately worsen this patient’s bleeding, particularly if it is from the upper gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic to evaluate shortness of breath and increased swelling of the lower extremities. He states, “I get so winded after only walking half a city block now that I think my heart failure is worsening.” Past medical history is notable for heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. The patient’s medications include atorvastatin, metformin, metoprolol, rivaroxaban, aspirin, and lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 64/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 174/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100%.  A beta-blockers examination is notable for bibasilar rales and 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities.  The patient is subsequently administered a medication that decreases cardiac contractility and increases the release of nitric oxide in the vasculature. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings suggestive of worsening heart failure. He is started on a medication that decreases cardiac contractility and increases the release of nitric oxide in the vasculature. He was most likely prescribed nebivolol.

Third-generation β-blockers such as carvedilol, labetalol, and nebivolol carry more than their typical β-blocking effects (e.g., decreased heart rate, decreased cardiac contractility). For instance, nebivolol has β1-blocking properties, which results in decreased cardiac contractility, and β3-receptor agonism properties. The latter results in nitric oxide synthase activation in the vasculature and a subsequent decrease in systemic vascular resistance.

On the other hand, Carvedilol and labetalol have not only β-blocking effects and some α-blocking effects, which lead to vasodilation. This combination makes these drugs exceptionally useful in acute hypertension management and the treatment of heart failure or myocardial infarction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nebivolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Esmolol:
Incorrect: Selective β-blockers such as acebutolol, atenolol, betaxolol, bisoprolol, esmolol, and  metoprolol preferentially affect β1-receptors, resulting in decreased heart rate and cardiac contractility. However, since these medications do not stimulate β3-receptors, they would not induce nitric oxide release.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a non-selective β-antagonist. It does have agonistic effects on β3-receptors and would not induce nitric oxide release.  
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem causes vasodilation via calcium channel blockade, not nitric oxide release.  
❌ Epinephrine:
Incorrect: Epinephrine is a non-selective β-agonist, which results in increased cardiac contractility and peripheral vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 66-year-old person presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. The patient is accompanied by their partner who reports the patient has gained 30 pounds in the past month with progressive shortness of breath and intermittent chest discomfort. Today, the patient was unable to speak in clear, full sentences and appeared “blue,” prompting their visit. The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, and a 40 pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 85% on room air. Cardiopulmonary auscultation reveals bilateral diffuse rales and an S3 gallop. The patient has cool lower extremities to touch along with 4+ pitting edema as well as a positive hepatojugular reflex. The patient is provided with intravenous furosemide and norepinephrine without change in vital signs or clinical status. Administration of which of the following medications is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with poorly controlled hypertension presents with features consistent with cardiogenic shock, including volume overload state (bilateral diffuse rales, pitting edema, and positive hepatojugular reflex), an S3 gallop, and cool extremities. Initial treatment with norepinephrine and intravenous diuresis failed to manage the clinical picture, making administration of dobutamine the next best step in management.    

Dobutamine, as a dominant ß1 agonist with minimal effects on ß2 receptors and alpha receptors, increases inotropy and chronotropy, making it an ideal agent for the treatment of cardiogenic shock and acute heart failure. Treatment of chronic heart failure with dobutamine is inappropriate due to lack of oral efficacy, tolerance, and arrhythmogenicity. Dobutamine, given its mechanism of action and short duration, is also used as a pharmacologic cardiac stress agent for patients that cannot tolerate exercise stress tests.    

The primary limiting factor of dobutamine is its arrhythmogenic profile. Selective ß1 agonism increases cardiac conduction abnormalities and, if used long-term, may worsen underlying cardiac ischemia. Therefore, dobutamine may only be used as a bridge to long-term vasopressor, diuretic, or mechanical cardiac therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Dobutamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is a pure alpha agonist and could potentially worsen this patient’s cardiac function via an increase in afterload.  
❌ Epinephrine:
Incorrect: Epinephrine is an α1, α2, ß1, ß2, and ß3 agonist and may be of potential benefit in this patient given its beta effects. However, its significant alpha effect makes dobutamine a more appropriate choice.  
❌ Isoproterenol:
Incorrect: Isoproterenol is the prototypical non-selective beta agonist and results in widened pulse pressure, increased heart rate, decreased peripheral resistance, and ultimately decreased mean arterial pressure. It is not clinically indicated in the treatment of cardiogenic shock.  
❌ Fenoldopam:
Incorrect: Fenoldopam only agonizes D1 receptors; it is not an appropriate medication for the treatment of cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with congestive heart failure comes to the office with exertional shortness of breath. He reports that he has to stop to catch his breath after climbing a flight of stairs. He has a history of multiple hospitalizations due to acute decompensation of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. The patient also has a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension and is on multiple medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, bibasilar lung crackles, and 2+ lower extremity pitting edema. After an appropriate workup, a decision is made to start the patient on digoxin therapy. Which of the following membrane ion channels is the primary target of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient with heart failure exacerbation is started on a positive inotropic medication (increases the strength of heart muscle contraction), digoxin. It acts by inhibiting the sodium/potassium ATPase pump at the cell membrane of the cardiomyocyte. Usually, the Na+/K+ ATPase moves two potassium ions into the cell for every three sodium ions out. With digoxin, potassium cannot enter the cell, and sodium can’t leave it, leading to a slight increase in intracellular sodium. The increased sodium alters the driving force for sodium-calcium exchange by the exchanger, NCX, so less calcium is removed from the cell. The increased intracellular calcium is stored in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This releases even more calcium into the cell via calcium-induced calcium release and increases contractile force (positive inotropy). Digoxin also exerts parasympathetic effects by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase found in vagal neurons' cell membrane, decreasing heart rate (negative chronotropy).
 

Option Analysis

❌ Sodium-calcium exchanger:
Incorrect: Digoxin does not directly act on the sodium-calcium exchanger but increases its function secondarily by accumulating intracellular sodium ions.  
✅ Sodium-potassium ATPase pump:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sodium channel:
Incorrect: Sodium channels in the myocytes are blocked by class I antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., procainamide, flecainide). They slow the upstroke of sodium-dependent action potentials and usually prolong QRS duration. They are not indicated in heart failure patients.  
❌ L-type calcium channel:
Incorrect: Class IV antiarrhythmics (e.g. verapamil) block the L-type calcium channel in cardiac pacemaker cells to decrease the conduction velocity of the sinoatrial node. These agents should be avoided in heart failure exacerbations.  
❌ Potassium channel:
Incorrect: Class III antiarrhythmics block the potassium channels responsible for repolarizing the action potential (AP). This results in an AP prolongation, an increase in the effective refractory period, and a reduced ability of the heart to respond to rapid tachycardias or fibrillation. It can precipitate bradycardia and heart failure and should be avoided in this patient.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with nonischemic cardiomyopathy and hypertension comes to the clinic for follow-up following recent hospital admission for acute decompensated heart failure. She becomes short of breath after walking a block but has not had syncope, cough, or hemoptysis. Her current medications include metoprolol, lisinopril, furosemide, spironolactone, and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> of 90%. An echocardiogram reveals an ejection fraction of 30%, mild mitral regurgitation, and pulmonary hypertension. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Ivabradine is added to her treatment regimen. Which of the following phases of the pacemaker action potential is targeted by this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptomatic heart failure (NYHA Class II-III) with reduced ejection fraction and is currently on optimal medical therapy with a diuretic, an ACE inhibitor, aldosterone antagonist, and a beta blocker. Ivabradine is a selective sinus node inhibitor that inhibits the funny sodium current that occurs through the HCN channels in the heart's pacemaker cells. As a result, this medication inhibits phase 4 of the cardiac pacemaker action potential.

Ivabradine is also indicated in the treatment of chronic stable angina in patients with chronic heart failure and a heart rate of >70 bpm. It is not beneficial in those with stable coronary artery disease without heart failure. Adverse effects of ivabradine include symptomatic bradycardia and visual disturbances (presence of phosphenes).
 



Option Analysis

❌ Phase 0:
Incorrect: Phase 0 depolarization depends on a calcium current via L-type calcium channels. These channels are inhibited by class IV antiarrhythmics like verapamil and diltiazem. Ivabradine does not inhibit L-type calcium channels.  
❌ Phase 2:
Incorrect: Phase 1 and 2 of the cardiac action potential are not present in pacemaker cells. Instead, phase 0 proceeds directly to phase 3. Ivabradine acts on cardiac pacemaker cells at phase 0 of their action potential.  
❌ Phase 3:
Incorrect: Phase 3 of the pacemaker action potential is governed by the decay of calcium channel current and repolarization driven by rectifying potassium channels. Ivabradine does not affect phase 3 of the pacemaker action potential.  
✅ Phase 4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phase 4 and Phase 0:
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers affect phase 4 and phase 0, slowing pacemaker potential and delaying depolarization of pacemaker tissue. While ivabradine does act on Phase 4 of the pacemaker potential, it does not affect phase 0 of the pacemaker action potential.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to shortness of breath for one day and a cough that developed one week ago. The symptoms have continued to worsen, and today she is having difficulty walking up the stairs in her home due to dyspnea. There is no associated chest pain. For the past three weeks, the patient has been using an extra pillow to prop her head up while sleeping at night. She was previously diagnosed with hypertension, but she has not seen a doctor in twenty years. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 170/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing with increased work of breathing. On pulmonary auscultation, there are faint wheezes in multiple lung fields and bibasilar crackles. There are no abnormal heart sounds. There is mild edema to the mid-calf bilaterally. A chest radiograph is ordered, and results shown below. Serum white blood cell count is 9,000/mm3. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Image added from Osmosis script.
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with worsening shortness of breath and cough in the setting of recent orthopnea, and signs of volume overload on exam (bibasilar crackles, lower extremity edema) likely has new onset congestive heart failure. The initial treatment involves diuresis with a loop diuretic (e.g., bumetanide, furosemide, torsemide) followed by additional testing to evaluate cardiac function and the underlying cause. Untreated hypertension is a common cause of congestive heart failure.    

Acute cough can be a presenting symptom of multiple cardiopulmonary pathologies and refers to a cough that has been present for less than 3 weeks. Patients presenting with acute cough who are unstable should be stabilized before further diagnostic testing. Once the patient is stabilized, a chest radiograph is performed which can help determine the diagnosis and severity based on the presence of radiographic abnormalities.    

Conditions to consider for patients with a new cough and a normal chest radiograph include gastroesophageal reflux disease, allergies, pulmonary embolism, viral bronchitis, and cough caused by medications such as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors.   

For patients with an abnormal chest radiograph, a dense infiltrate or opacity may indicate bacterial pneumonia, while chronic bronchiectasis changes and new tram-track opacities may indicate a bronchiectasis exacerbation in patients with known bronchiectasis. Patients with signs and symptoms consistent with volume overload may have new onset or exacerbation of congestive heart failure (CHF). Signs of CHF include clinical findings such as peripheral edema and pulmonary crackles and radiographic findings may include pleural effusion, pulmonary edema, Kerley B lines, and an enlarged heart. Patients with CHF often experience orthopnea and paroxysmal dyspnea. While wheezing is often associated with obstructive lung disease, mild wheezing can also be present in CHF exacerbation.    

Option Analysis

✅ Furosemide:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Metolazone:
Incorrect: Metolazone is a thiazide-like diuretic. This type of diuretic can be used to augment diuresis when given with a loop diuretic but is not appropriate monotherapy for active diuresis in patients with congestive heart failure. 
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Antibiotics like Ceftriaxone are indicated in pneumonia treatment. This patient’s history, normal temperature, physical exam findings, chest X-ray findings, and lack of leukocytosis are more consistent with congestive heart failure than acute infection. 
❌ Levofloxacin:
Incorrect: Levofloxacin is appropriate monotherapy for community-acquired pneumonia. This patient’s history, normal temperature, physical exam findings, chest X-ray findings, and lack of leukocytosis are more consistent with congestive heart failure than acute infection.  
❌ Enoxaparin:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous enoxaparin is used as anticoagulant in patients with pulmonary embolism. This patient’s lack of chest pain, normal heart rate, and bilateral calf swelling (swelling is typically unilateral in deep vein thrombosis) makes pulmonary embolism less likely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old previously healthy woman presents to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath, chest pain, and palpitations over the past 48 hours. She describes the chest pain as dull discomfort that is not relieved by rest. Initially, she became short of breath with minimal exertion, but since the morning she has been unable to lie flat due to increasing shortness of breath. She recalls feeling fatigued with low-grade fevers one week ago, which she attributed to an upper respiratory illness. Temperature is 37°C (98.6), blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg, heart rate is 125 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On physical examination, there is jugular venous distension, bilateral rales on lung auscultation, and heart sounds reveal a prominent S3 gallop without a murmur. There is pitting edema in the lower extremities bilaterally. Peripheral pulses are weak and thready. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) reveals global hypokinesis, biventricular dilation, and a severely reduced ejection fraction of 25%. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with fulminant myocarditis, which is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by rapid deterioration in cardiac function that can lead to cardiogenic shock. Fulminant myocarditis can cause severe left and right ventricular dysfunction, leading to poor cardiac output and circulatory failure. Immediate management should follow the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure), starting with airway stabilization first with supplemental oxygen and possibly with intubation and mechanical ventilation and circulatory support.        

The patient's hypotension and low oxygen saturation require urgent stabilization, including oxygen and possible mechanical ventilation. Inotropic circulatory support with agents like dopamine should be provided and mechanical circulatory support (MCS), with intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may be needed to maintain perfusion until myocardial inflammation resolves or a definitive treatment (e.g., heart transplantation) is performed.    

Option Analysis

✅ Supplemental oxygen:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rest and physical activity restriction:
Incorrect: Rest and activity restriction may be appropriate for mild cases of myocarditis, but are not suitable for this patient, who presents in cardiogenic shock due to fulminant myocarditis. Immediate stabilization of the airway and circulatory system is required in this critical scenario.  
❌ High-dose corticosteroids:
Incorrect: High-dose corticosteroids may be considered to treat myocarditis, but this hemodynamically unstable patient should first be stabilized, and oxygen should be provided.  
❌ Coronary angiography:
Incorrect: Coronary angiography is used to evaluate for coronary artery disease. This patient’s presentation of early age and lack of risk factors for ischemic heart disease is more suggestive of myocarditis. 
❌ Endomyocardial biopsy:
Incorrect: An endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis; however, it is not the immediate priority in this critically ill, unstable patient. Stabilization through airway management and circulatory support should take precedence before further diagnostic studies are pursued.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening shortness of breath for the past three weeks. The patient's partner called EMS when the patient collapsed after standing up from the couch. The patient has a past medical history of heart failure, hypertension, diabetes, and a 20 pack-year smoking history. Medications include aspirin, amlodipine, carvedilol, metformin, and furosemide. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 76/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient is ill-appearing, diaphoretic, and tachypneic at rest. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals distended neck veins, distant heart sounds, and bibasilar rales. ECG is notable for low-voltage QRS complexes in all leads. A bedside ultrasound is performed, which is displayed below. One of the findings is a large pericardial effusion. Which of the following is the best initial step in management while waiting for emergency staff to collect procedure supplies?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical, ECG, and echocardiographic findings (pericardial fluid and right ventricular collapse) consistent with cardiac tamponade. The patient is hemodynamically unstable due to obstructive shock because of associated right heart failure. In this setting, it is necessary to administer intravenous fluids to maximize right ventricular preload while preparing for urgent pericardial drainage.        

Right heart failure occurs when the right side of the heart fails to adequately perfuse the pulmonary arterial circulation, resulting in elevated central venous pressure. In the acute setting, patients may often present with shortness of breath; chest pain; and may demonstrate physical examination findings suggestive of right heart dysfunction, including distended neck veins, diaphoresis, hypotension, and tachycardia. Additional cardiac examination findings can include right ventricular (RV) heave, loud P2 (if pulmonary hypertension is present), and a right-sided S3.        

When cardiogenic or obstructive shock secondary to right heart failure is suspected, patients should undergo an ABCDE assessment. All patients should be placed on continuous vital sign monitoring and have IV access placed. Immediate stabilization measures may include endotracheal intubation for associated respiratory failure and hemodynamic support, depending on the clinical scenario.
